choices.text: External branch of the superior laryngeal
Internal branch of the superior laryngeal

questions.text: Following thyroid surgery, a patient presents with frequent aspiration and complete loss of sensation in both piriform recesses above the vocal folds. On examination, the mucosa of the laryngeal inlet and supraglottic region is found to be numb bilaterally. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the mucosa above the vocal cords, including the piriform recess; its bilateral injury leads to loss of protective reflexes and aspiration risk.

  • The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (from the vagus nerve) penetrates the thyrohyoid membrane and innervates:
    • Mucosa of the laryngeal inlet, piriform recess, and supraglottic larynx
    • Part of the pharyngeal wall
  • It is sensory, and loss of this input (especially bilaterally) results in:
    • Impaired cough reflex
    • Silent aspiration (fluids/food entering airway without triggering reflex)
  • This nerve is at risk during thyroid surgery due to its course near the superior thyroid vessels.

Explanation of other options:

External branch of the superior laryngeal (Option A): Provides motor innervation to cricothyroid muscle, affecting voice pitch, not sensory innervation to piriform recess.

Hypoglossal nerve (Option B): Innervates extrinsic tongue muscles; unrelated to laryngeal or pharyngeal sensation.

Lingual nerve (Option D): Provides general sensation to anterior 2/3 of the tongue, not to the piriform recess or larynx.

questions.text: The laryngeal muscle most responsible for stretching (elongating) the vocal ligament is the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The cricothyroid muscle tilts the thyroid cartilage forward, thereby stretching and tensing the vocal ligaments to increase pitch.

  • The cricothyroid is the only intrinsic laryngeal muscle located externally and is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (branch of CN X).
  • Action:
    • Pulls the thyroid cartilage anteroinferiorly towards the cricoid cartilage.
    • This elongates and tenses the vocal ligaments, which raises the pitch of the voice.
  • It plays a key role in phonation, especially high-pitched sounds.

questions.text: Identify the muscle most responsible for the abduction of the vocal folds.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The posterior cricoarytenoid is the only muscle that abducts the vocal folds, marked as 1 in the image.

  • This muscle is innervated by the inferior laryngeal nerve, which is a continuation of the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
  • If this muscle is denervated, the vocal folds may be paralyzed in an adducted position, which would prevent air from entering the trachea.
  • Arytenoid, lateral cricoarytenoid, and thyroarytenoid all adduct the vocal folds.
  • Cricothyroid is the only laryngeal muscle innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal. It tenses the vocal ligaments by tipping the thyroid cartilage forward relative to the cricoid cartilage.

questions.text: The nerve that innervates all the muscle of larynx except cricothyroid muscle-
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The inferior laryngeal nerve, a terminal branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve, supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid.

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus nerve, CN X) ascends in the tracheoesophageal groove and becomes the inferior laryngeal nerve as it enters the larynx.
  • It supplies motor innervation to:
    • Posterior cricoarytenoid
    • Lateral cricoarytenoid
    • Thyroarytenoid
    • Transverse and oblique arytenoids
    • Vocalis
  • Exception: The cricothyroid muscle is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, not by the inferior laryngeal nerve.

Explanation of other options:

Glossopharyngeal nerve, pharyngeal branch (Option A): Supplies stylopharyngeus and pharyngeal mucosa; has no role in laryngeal muscle innervation.

Superior laryngeal nerve, external branch (Option C): Supplies only the cricothyroid muscle; does not supply other intrinsic laryngeal muscles.

Superior laryngeal nerve, internal branch (Option D): Is sensory only, providing sensation to the supraglottic larynx and piriform recess, not motor.

questions.text: The vocalis muscle is most responsible for the fine control of phonation because of its attachment into the
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The vocalis muscle inserts directly into the vocal ligament, allowing fine tension adjustments essential for precise control of pitch modulation during phonation.

  • Its origin: Inner surface of thyroid cartilage (angle)
  • Its insertion: Vocal ligament and vocal process of arytenoid cartilage
  • Its unique feature is that fibers insert directly into the vocal ligament, enabling:
    • Minute adjustments in tension
    • Control of frequency and quality of voice
    • Smooth modulation between pitches (especially during speech and singing)
  • It is innervated by the inferior laryngeal nerve, a branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve (CN X).

choices.text: Vagus nerve via the pharyngeal plexus

questions.text: The constrictor muscles of the pharynx receive their motor nerve supply from the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The vagus nerve (CN X) provides motor innervation to all pharyngeal constrictor muscles via the pharyngeal plexus.

  • The pharynx has three constrictor muscles: superior, middle, and inferior constrictors.
  • These muscles form the outer muscular coat of the pharynx and are responsible for sequential contraction during swallowing, propelling the food bolus downward.
    • Motor innervation: All constrictors are supplied by pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve (CN X), through the pharyngeal plexus.
      • The pharyngeal plexus is formed by contributions from:
        • Vagus nerve (motor)
        • Glossopharyngeal nerve (sensory)
        • Sympathetic fibers
  • Exception: The stylopharyngeus (a longitudinal muscle) is supplied directly by glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

Explanation of other options:

Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option A): Supplies stylopharyngeus only; does not supply the constrictors.

Hypoglossal nerve (Option C): Supplies muscles of the tongue, not the pharynx.

Recurrent laryngeal nerve (Option D): Supplies intrinsic laryngeal muscles, not the pharyngeal constrictors.

questions.text: A patient has occasional blackouts and light-headedness. Studies reveal atherosclerotic plaques within the common carotid arteries and the bifurcation of the vessels. A carotid endarterectomy is undertaken. Which nerve bundle running vertically within the carotid sheath must the surgeon be careful not to injure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The vagus nerve (CN X) runs vertically within the carotid sheath, between the internal jugular vein and common carotid artery, and is at risk during carotid endarterectomy.

  • The carotid sheath is a fascial compartment in the neck enclosing:
    • Medially: Common/internal carotid artery
    • Laterally: Internal jugular vein
    • Posteriorly and between them: Vagus nerve (CN X)
  • During carotid endarterectomy (surgical removal of plaque from the carotid artery), dissection near the carotid bifurcation can inadvertently injure:
    • The vagus nerve, leading to hoarseness, dysphagia, or vocal cord paralysis due to involvement of recurrent laryngeal nerve branches.
  • The vagus nerve gives off cardiac branches, pharyngeal branches, and continues inferiorly into the thorax and abdomen.

Explanation of other options:

Accessory nerve (Option A): Travels posterior to the carotid sheath, and primarily innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius; not inside the sheath.

Cervical sympathetic trunk (Option B): Lies posterior and medial to the carotid sheath, not within it; supplies sympathetic innervation, not directly at risk in the sheath.

Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option C): Lies more superiorly and exits the skull via the jugular foramen, gives off carotid sinus branch, but does not run within the sheath vertically.

questions.text: While doing a postoperative physical examination on a patient who has undergone carotid endarterectomy on the right side, it was noted that the tongue deviated toward the right when the patient was asked to point the tongue outward. What nerve crossing the carotid artery must have been injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The hypoglossal nerve crosses the carotid artery before diving into the floor of the mouth, so it might get injured during this procedure.

  • Hypoglossal nerve innervates the muscles of the tongue.
  • When the hypoglossal nerve is injured and a patient sticks out the tongue, the tongue points to the side with the injured nerve.
  • So, this patient, who had the right side endarterectomy, has an injury to the right hypoglossal nerve.
  • The symptoms in this case point towards suspecting damage to the hypoglossal nerve.
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve crosses around the internal carotid artery and the stylopharyngeus muscle, it could theoretically be injured in this procedure, but the symptoms are not consistent with an injury to this structure.
  • The inferior alveolar nerve and lingual nerves are branches of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve.
  • They are not associated with the carotid vessels.
  • The vagus nerve is found in the carotid sheath. This nerve can be easily injured by an endarterectomy, although damage to the vagus would cause problems with swallowing, not with tongue movements.

choices.text: External branch of the superior laryngeal
Inferior root of the ansa cervicalis
Internal branch of the superior laryngeal

questions.text: Any manipulation of the superior thyroid artery must be undertaken with care not to damage its small companion nerve, the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve runs in close relation to the superior thyroid artery and may be injured during its ligation.

  • The superior thyroid artery arises from the external carotid artery and descends to the upper pole of the thyroid gland.
  • Closely related to it is the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, which runs inferomedially along with or just deep to the artery.
  • This nerve innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which:
    • Tenses and elongates the vocal cords
    • Modulates voice pitch (especially for high-pitched sounds)
  • Injury during thyroid surgery (e.g., ligation of the superior thyroid artery) can cause:
    • Monotone voice
    • Reduced vocal pitch control
  • In contrast, the inferior thyroid artery (branch of thyrocervical trunk) runs posteriorly and is closely related to the recurrent laryngeal nerve , another critical structure at risk during thyroid surgery.

questions.text: The carotid body is innervated by a branch of the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The carotid body is innervated by the carotid branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve.

  • It is a small, reddish-brown ovoid mass that lies on the medial side of the carotid bifurcation, serving as a chemoreceptor that monitors the level of carbon dioxide in the blood.
  • The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) innervates the muscles of the tongue. (Option B ruled out)
  • The spinal accessory nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the sternocleidomastoid and the trapezius. (Option C ruled out)
  • The sympathetic trunk provides sympathetic innervation to the head and neck. (Option D ruled out)
  • Finally, the vagus nerve supplies motor innervation to the muscles of the pharynx and larynx, with the exception of stylopharyngeus, and the muscles of the palate, with the exception of tensor veli palatini.

questions.text: Which of the following cartilage does not ossify with age?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A and D are epiglottis and corniculate cartilage respectively. They are made of elastic cartilage, which does not ossify with age, unlike the hyaline cartilages of the larynx.

  • Laryngeal cartilages are either hyaline or elastic:
    • Hyaline cartilage (e.g., thyroid, cricoid, arytenoid): Undergoes ossification with age.
    • Elastic cartilage (e.g., epiglottis, corniculate, cuneiform): Remains flexible and does not ossify.
  • The epiglottis is a leaf-shaped elastic cartilage that prevents food from entering the larynx during swallowing. Its elastic nature is essential for its protective function.
  • The corniculate cartilages are elastic. They are small paired nodules situated on arytenoids.

questions.text: What is the type of cartilage marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked cartilage is Triticeal cartilage and its Hyaline in nature.

  • Triticeal cartilage is a small cartilage in the lateral thyrohyoid ligament
  • The thyrohyoid membrane is a tough fibrous-elastic ligament that spans between the superior margin of the thyroid cartilage below and the hyoid bone above.
  • It is attached to the superior margin of the thyroid laminae and adjacent anterior margins of the superior horns, and ascends medially to the greater horns and posterior to the body of the hyoid bone to attach to the superior margins of these structures.
  • The posterior borders of the thyrohyoid membrane are thickened to form the lateral thyrohyoid ligaments.
  • The membrane is also thickened anteriorly in the midline to form the median thyrohyoid ligament.
  • It consists of hyaline cartilage, which provides rigidity and support.
  • With advancing age, hyaline cartilage is prone to calcification and ossification, making it radiopaque in older individuals.

choices.text: 20 years in males and 22 years in females
14 years in males and 11 years in females
13 years in males and 8 years in females
18 years in males and 16 years in females

questions.text: When does thyroid cartilage ossify approximately ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thyroid cartilage, composed of hyaline cartilage, begins to ossify around 20 years in males and 22 years in females.

  • The ossification of the thyroid cartilage is an age-related physiological process.
  • Being hyaline cartilage, it tends to calcify and ossify progressively with age, often visible on imaging.
  • In males, ossification begins earlier (around 20 years) due to earlier pubertal hormonal influence.
  • In females, this process starts slightly later (around 22 years).
  • The process continues throughout life and can be quite pronounced in the elderly.
  • The ossified cartilages are subjected to fracture in cases of trauma as it ossifies.

choices.text: Internal laryngeal nerve and stylopharyngeus muscle
Internal laryngeal vein and Digastric muscle

questions.text: The image given below is the constrictors of the pharynx. Identify B in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure marked B in the image corresponds to the stylopharyngeus muscle piercing the middle and superior constrictors, accompanied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

  • The stylopharyngeus muscle is the only muscle supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and plays a role in elevating the pharynx during swallowing.
  • It passes between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors.
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve travels along with it to reach the pharyngeal wall and posterior 1/3 of the tongue, supplying sensory innervation.
  • This anatomic relationship is a key landmark in surgical anatomy of the pharynx.

Explanation of other options:

Vagus nerve and Digastric muscle (Option A): The vagus nerve (CN X) runs in the carotid sheath, but it does not accompany stylopharyngeus, and the digastric muscle is more superficial and not seen piercing pharyngeal constrictors.

Internal laryngeal nerve and stylopharyngeus muscle (Option C): The internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (CN X), pierces the thyrohyoid membrane, not the pharyngeal constrictors, and does not travel with stylopharyngeus.

Internal laryngeal vein and Digastric muscle (Option D): The internal laryngeal vein is small and related to the thyrohyoid region, and digastric is not associated with the pharyngeal wall or stylopharyngeus.

choices.text: Recurrent laryngeal nerve and the inferior laryngeal artery
Recurrent laryngeal nerve and the superior laryngeal artery
Recurrent laryngeal nerve and the Glossopharyngeal nerve
Recurrent laryngeal nerve and the thyroid artery

questions.text: What passes through the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal artery pass deep to the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle to enter the larynx.

  • Gaps between muscles of the pharyngeal wall provide important routes for muscles and neurovascular tissues.
  • The gap between the middle and inferior constrictor muscles allows the internal laryngeal vessels and nerve access to the aperture in the thyrohyoid membrane to enter the larynx.
  • The recurrent laryngeal nerves and accompanying inferior laryngeal vessels enter the larynx posterior to the inferior horn of the thyroid cartilage deep to the inferior margin of the inferior constrictor muscle.

questions.text: Which of the tonsils forms the inferior part of the waldeyer ring?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lingual tonsil refers to numerous lymphoid nodules located within the submucosa of the posterior third of the tongue. It forms the inferior aspect of Waldeyer's ring.

  • This tonsil is responsible for the irregularappearance of the posterior tongue surface. and forms the inferior part of Waldeyer's ring.
  • Like the rest of the tongue, the lingual tonsil is covered by a stratified non-keratinised squamous epithelium.
  • Waldeyer's ring is a ring of lymphoid tissue in the pharynx that forms the first line of immune defense in the upper respiratory and digestive tracts.
  • It surrounds the nasal and oropharynx and includes:
    • Nasopharyngeal tonsil (adenoids) - superior (Option B ruled out)
    • Tubal tonsils - lateral (Option D ruled out)
    • Palatine tonsils - lateral (Option A ruled out)
    • Lingual tonsil - inferior
  • The lingual tonsil consists of lymphoid tissue at the posterior part of the tongue, beneath the mucosa of the dorsum of the tongue, and plays a role in trapping pathogens entering via the oral cavity.

choices.text: It is located in the lateral wall of the oropharynx between the palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal arches.
It receives arterial supply from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery, among others.
The tonsillar bed is formed by the superior pharyngeal constrictor and the styloglossus muscle.
It drains into the jugulodigastric lymph node, which is a key node in tonsillar infections.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the marked structure is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure is palatine tonsil. The tonsillar bed is not formed by the styloglossus. It is formed by the superior constrictor muscle and pharyngobasilar fascia.

  • The palatine tonsil lies in the tonsillar fossa, located between these two folds in the lateral wall of the oropharynx. (Option A ruled out)
  • The facial artery (tonsillar branch) is the main blood supply. Other contributors include branches from the ascending palatine artery, dorsal lingual artery, ascending pharyngeal artery, and greater palatine artery. (Option B ruled out)
  • The jugulodigastric node (also called the tonsillar node) is enlarged in infections like tonsillitis and acts as the primary drainage site. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the clinic for a follow-up after hospitalization. He was hospitalized two weeks ago for pneumonia and was treated with ampicillin-sulbactam. Medical history is notable for type DM type 2 and aortic stenosis. Further medical history reveals 2 prior hospitalizations in the past year for Pneumonia. The patient reports difficulty swallowing and regurgitation of undigested food particles. A barium esophagram is performed and shown below:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Barium esophagram shows a posterior outpouching at the pharyngoesophageal junction, classic for Zenker's diverticulum.

  • Zenker's diverticulum, also known as pharyngoesophageal diverticulum, is a pharyngeal pouch that forms where the lower part of the throat and the upper part of the esophagus meet.
  • It is most common in older adults. If left untreated, it can negatively affect quality of life and can put a person at increased risk of aspiration and choking.
  • Zenker's diverticulum develops when the muscle between the throat and esophagus, known as the cricopharyngeus muscle, over-tightens, causing the throat above it to pouch out.
  • Over time, the pouch can enlarge as the muscles below it tighten excessively.
  • Food can catch in this pouch or it can cause an obstruction.
  • It can also make it difficult to take medications - particularly pills, which could get caught.
  • On barium swallow, it appears as a posterior midline outpouching just above the upper esophageal sphincter.

Explanation of other options:

Carcinoma esophagus (Option B): Would show irregular narrowing or mass-like lesion, not a smooth posterior pouch. Also, history would be more progressive dysphagia and weight loss.

Barrett esophagus (Option C): A histologic diagnosis, not typically visualized in barium studies. It shows columnar metaplasia in lower esophagus due to GERD.

Tracheoesophageal fistula (Option D): Usually presents in infants (if congenital), or in adults after trauma or malignancy. Barium swallow would show contrast entering the tracheobronchial tree, not a localized posterior pouch.
